Q: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, he is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Catatonic schizophrenia (B) Heat stroke (C) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (D) Oversedation
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, he is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Catatonic schizophrenia (B) Heat stroke (C) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (D) Oversedation
outputs:
The patient has been undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. He is uncooperative and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry. The most likely diagnosis is heat stroke. The patient has been exposed to high temperatures, and his vital signs suggest that he is experiencing heat-related stress. The patient's confusion, agitation, and rigidity also support this diagnosis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 67-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department by her family after they found her unresponsive in her bed. The patient has a history of falls, and her family reports that she has been complaining of headaches and blurred vision for the past week. The patient is currently taking metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The patient is unresponsive, but breathing and has a pulse. Her blood pressure is 188/108 mm Hg, and her respirations are 8/min. The patient's pupils are fixed and dilated. There is no evidence of trauma. A head CT scan without contrast shows a large intracerebral hemorrhage involving the right hemisphere. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administration of activated charcoal (B) Administration of intravenous furosemide (C) Administration of intravenous labetalol (D) Endotracheal intubation
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. She has been complaining of headaches and blurred vision for the past week. The patient is unresponsive, but breathing and has a pulse. Her blood pressure is 188/108 mm Hg, and her respirations are 8/min. The patient's pupils are fixed and dilated. There is no evidence of trauma. A head CT scan without contrast shows a large intracerebral hemorrhage involving the right hemisphere. The most likely diagnosis is a ruptured aneurysm. The patient requires immediate neurosurgical intervention. The answer is (D).

Q: A 42-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis and hypothyroidism presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of worsening bilateral wrist pain. She has been taking naproxen and prednisone as prescribed by her rheumatologist. She has no history of previous joint surgery. She appears comfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling and erythema of the wrists. There is no warmth or redness of the hands. The patient has full range of motion of the wrists. The patient has normal muscle strength and no sensory deficits. The patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h, and C-reactive protein is 2.5 mg/dL. She has a 2-week history of worsening bilateral wrist pain. The patient appears comfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling and erythema of the wrists. Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. She gave birth to a healthy baby boy three days prior to presentation. Since then, she has been feeling sick, and she is concerned that she has been getting worse over time. On presentation, her temperature is 100.7°F (38.1°C), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical exam reveals abdominal discomfort with uterine tenderness, and laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count with many plasma cells. The most likely cause of this patient's disorder has which of the following characteristics?
(A) Alpha-hemolytic cocci in chains (B) Beta-hemolytic cocci in chains (C) Coagulase-positive cocci in clusters (D) Gamma-hemolytic cocci in chains
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. She gave birth to a healthy baby boy three days prior to presentation. Since then, she has been feeling sick, and she is concerned that she has been getting worse over time. On presentation, her temperature is 100.7°F (38.1°C), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 14/min. The most likely cause of this patient's disorder has which of the following characteristics?
options: (A) Alpha-hemolytic cocci in chains (B) Beta-hemolytic cocci in chains (C) Coagulase-positive cocci in clusters (D) Gamma-hemolytic cocci in chains
outputs:
The patient has abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. She gave birth to a healthy baby boy three days prior to presentation. She has been feeling sick, and she is concerned that she has been getting worse over time. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest that she may have an infection. The laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count with many plasma cells, which is consistent with an infection. The most likely cause of the patient's disorder is a bacterial infection. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with endometritis, which is an infection of the uterine lining. The most likely cause of endometritis is a bacterial infection. The answer is (C).

Q: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-day history of worsening headache, fever, and nausea. She has been vomiting once or twice a day. She has no significant medical history. On physical examination, her temperature is 102.6°F (39.2°C), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 18/min. There is no meningism, and the neurological examination is otherwise normal. Complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm3, with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Viral meningitis (B) Bacterial meningitis (C) Encephalitis (D) Acute sinusitis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-day history of worsening headache, fever, and nausea. She has been vomiting once or twice a day. She has no significant medical history. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest that she may have a central nervous system infection. The complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm3, with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils, which is consistent with a bacterial infection. The most likely diagnosis is bacterial meningitis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 58-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of knee trauma. She appears uncomfortable. The knee is swollen and warm, with moderate effusion. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and her pulse is 96/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order radiographs of the knee (B) Order an MRI of the knee (C) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole (D) Administer intravenous furosemide
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of knee trauma. The knee is swollen and warm, with moderate effusion. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest that she may have an infection. The most appropriate next step in management would be to order radiographs of the knee to evaluate for any bone or joint abnormalities. The answer is (A).

Q: An 18-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician because his mother is concerned about his walking. The boy was born at 37 weeks’ gestation and spent 1 night in the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress. He otherwise has been healthy and started walking independently at 12 months. However, his mother reports that he has stopped walking and appears weaker than he was a few months ago. He also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. His parents are both healthy with no medical conditions. On exam, the child demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. He is unable to stand or sit up straight. His patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. This patient’s condition is caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
(A) Alpha-galactosidase A (B) Arylsulfatase A (C) Beta-galactocerebrosidase (D) Hexosaminidase A
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: An 18-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician because his mother is concerned about his walking. The boy was born at 37 weeks’ gestation and spent 1 night in the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress. He otherwise has been healthy and started walking independently at 12 months. However, his mother reports that he has stopped walking and appears weaker than he was a few months ago. He also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. His parents are both healthy with no medical conditions. On exam, the child demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. He is unable to stand or sit up straight. His patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. This patient’s condition is caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
options: (A) Alpha-galactosidase A (B) Arylsulfatase A (C) Beta-galactocerebrosidase (D) Hexosaminidase A
outputs:
The patient has a history of premature birth and was in the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress. He otherwise has been healthy and started walking independently at 12 months. However, his mother reports that he has stopped walking and appears weaker than he was a few months ago. He also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. The patient demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. He is unable to stand or sit up straight. His patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a lysosomal storage disorder. The metachromic granules in the urine are consistent with a diagnosis of Gaucher disease. The answer is (A).

Q: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of left-sided weakness, facial droop, and difficulty speaking. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 188/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows left hemiparesis, left facial droop, and dysarthria. There is no sensory loss or decreased reflexes. The patient is alert and able to follow commands. A noncontrast head CT shows an acute left middle cerebral artery territory infarction. The patient is given intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous heparin (B) Administer subcutaneous heparin (C) Perform cardiac echocardiography (D) Administer intravenous aspirin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He has a sudden onset of left-sided weakness, facial droop, and difficulty speaking. Physical examination shows left hemiparesis, left facial droop, and dysarthria. There is no sensory loss or decreased reflexes. The patient is alert and able to follow commands. A noncontrast head CT shows an acute left middle cerebral artery territory infarction. The patient is given intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous aspirin. Aspirin is used to prevent further platelet aggregation, which may help to reduce the risk of further infarction. The answer is (D).

Q: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiates to her left arm and jaw. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a blood pressure cuff on her left arm, which is at 190/100 mm Hg. There is a soft systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The patient is alert and able to follow commands. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V2 to V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (B) Administer intravenous furosemide (C) Perform coronary angiography (D) Administer intravenous metoprolol
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has a sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiates to her left arm and jaw. Physical examination shows a blood pressure cuff on her left arm, which is at 190/100 mm Hg. There is a soft systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for two weeks of low-grade fever and sore throat. Upon further questioning, the patient is found to have unprotected sex with both men and women with 3-5 partners per month. On workup, he is found to have an HIV viral load of 15,000 copies/mL with a CD4+ of 170 cells/mm^3. He is started on medical therapy. What should be included in his medication regimen?
(A) Azithromycin (B) Fluconazole (C) Folinic acid (D) Tetrahydrofolic acid
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for two weeks of low-grade fever and sore throat. Upon further questioning, the patient is found to have unprotected sex with both men and women with 3-5 partners per month. On workup, he is found to have an HIV viral load of 15,000 copies/mL with a CD4+ of 170 cells/mm^3. He is started on medical therapy. What should be included in his medication regimen?
options: (A) Azithromycin (B) Fluconazole (C) Folinic acid (D) Tetrahydrofolic acid
outputs:
The patient has a low-grade fever and sore throat, which could be caused by HIV. The patient has an HIV viral load of 15,000 copies/mL and a CD4+ of 170 cells/mm^3, which confirms the diagnosis of HIV. The patient also reports unprotected sex with both men and women, which puts him at risk for sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The patient should be started on antiretroviral therapy (ART) to treat HIV and prevent STIs. The medication regimen should include a combination of three drugs, including a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), and a protease inhibitor. Folinic acid is a form of folic acid that is used to treat folic acid deficiency, which is a common side effect of antiretroviral therapy. Tetrahydrofolic acid is a form of folic acid that is used to treat folic acid deficiency, which is a common side effect of antiretroviral therapy. The answer is (C).

Q: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, and difficulty speaking. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform gonioscopy. The answer is (B).

question: Q: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on her left foot. She has had decreased appetite and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months. Physical examination shows that on the left medial ankle there is a 2-cm reddish-black nodule with a verrucous surface. A full-thickness excisional biopsy of the lesion shows S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells. A subsequent CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows metastases to the liver; a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma is made. Chemotherapy with aldesleukin is initiated. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for this drug?
options: (A) Stimulating release of acute-phase reactants (B) Stimulating antigen-processing cells (C) Activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells (D) Supporting growth of bone marrow stem cells
outputs:
The patient has a pigmented lesion on her left foot. The biopsy shows S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells. The diagnosis is metastatic melanoma. Aldesleukin is a drug that is used to treat metastatic melanoma. It is an immunostimulant that works by activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells, which can help to kill cancer cells. The mechanism of action of aldesleukin is (C) activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells. The answer is (C).

The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a neoplasm of the thyroid. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?
(A) Papillary carcinoma (B) Medullary carcinoma (C) Follicular carcinoma (D) Anaplastic carcinoma
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a neoplasm of the thyroid. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?
options: (A) Papillary carcinoma (B) Medullary carcinoma (C) Follicular carcinoma (D) Anaplastic carcinoma
outputs:
The patient presents with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. This suggests that the nodule is likely to be a benign tumor. The most common benign tumor of the thyroid is a thyroidectomy. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe back pain, fever, and chills. He has a history of IV drug abuse and has recently been treated for a urinary tract infection. He is currently taking no medications. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F), respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine without any focal neurological deficits. The patient has a history of IV drug abuse and has recently been treated for a urinary tract infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Pyelonephritis (B) Pneumonia (C) Osteomyelitis (D) Endocarditis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of IV drug abuse and has recently been treated for a urinary tract infection. He presents with fever, chills, and severe back pain. The patient's symptoms and history suggest that the most likely diagnosis is pyelonephritis. The patient's fever and chills suggest that there is an infection, and the patient's history of IV drug abuse increases the likelihood that the infection is pyelonephritis. The patient's back pain could be caused by a kidney infection. The answer is (A).

Q: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive, painless swelling of her left breast. She also notices that her left nipple has been inverted for the past month. She has no other symptoms. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 5-cm mass in the left breast that is firm, round, and nontender. The nipple is inverted. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. A mammogram shows a 5-cm mass with irregular margins. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Excisional biopsy (B) Fine-needle aspiration (C) Ultrasonography (D) MRI
A: Let's think step by step. The patient presents with a 6-month history of progressive, painless swelling of her left breast. She also notices that her left nipple has been inverted for the past month. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is breast cancer. The patient's age and history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia also increase the likelihood of breast cancer. A mammogram shows a 5-cm mass with irregular margins, which supports the diagnosis of breast cancer. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform an excisional biopsy to confirm the diagnosis of breast cancer. The answer is (A).

Q: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain. She also has had fever, nausea, and vomiting. She has been menstruating for the past 2 days. She has no other symptoms. Her past medical history is significant for a history of pelvic inflammatory disease. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender, guarded right lower quadrant abdomen.

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 58-year-old male presents with an acutely elevated blood pressure of 220/140 mmHg. The patient complains of a headache and chest pain, and he has been vomiting for the last several hours. Physical exam demonstrates papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. To treat this patient's hypertensive emergency, he is started on an IV medication commonly used in this situation. The agent exerts its effect by releasing nitric oxide as a metabolite, which subsequently activates guanylate cyclase and increases production of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle. Which of the following clinical effects would be expected from administration of this medication?
(A) Decreased cardiac contractility (B) Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (C) Decreased stroke volume (D) Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 58-year-old male presents with an acutely elevated blood pressure of 220/140 mmHg. The patient complains of a headache and chest pain, and he has been vomiting for the last several hours. Physical exam demonstrates papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. To treat this patient's hypertensive emergency, he is started on an IV medication commonly used in this situation. The agent exerts its effect by releasing nitric oxide as a metabolite, which subsequently activates guanylate cyclase and increases production of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle. Which of the following clinical effects would be expected from administration of this medication?
options: (A) Decreased cardiac contractility (B) Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (C) Decreased stroke volume (D) Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
outputs:
The patient has acutely elevated blood pressure, headache, chest pain, and vomiting. His physical examination shows papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. This is consistent with a hypertensive emergency. The medication used to treat hypertensive emergencies is sodium nitroprusside. Sodium nitroprusside releases nitric oxide as a metabolite, which activates guanylate cyclase and increases production of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle. This causes vasodilation and decreases blood pressure. The answer is (D).

Q: A 65-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity presents with a 3-day history of worsening left knee pain. She denies any recent trauma or injuries. On physical examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. The patient has marked tenderness to palpation over the medial aspect of the left knee, and there is a mild effusion. No other joints are tender or swollen. Radiographs of the knee show a lateral femoral condylar lesion consistent with a meniscal tear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Arthroscopy (B) MRI of the knee (C) Intra-articular corticosteroid injection (D) Physical therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has worsening left knee pain for 3 days. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. She has marked tenderness to palpation over the medial aspect of the left knee and a mild effusion. Radiographs of the knee show a lateral femoral condylar lesion consistent with a meniscal tear. The patient has a meniscal tear. The next step would be to manage the meniscal tear. The most appropriate next step in management is (A) Arthroscopy.

Q: A 29-year-old woman with a history of migraines presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has tried over-the-counter pain medications without relief. On physical examination, her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. She appears uncomfortable and is unable to lie flat due to the pain. There is no evidence of a focal neurological deficit. Complete blood count and serum electrolyte levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer IV hydromorphone (B) Administer IV metoclopramide (C) Administer IV sumatriptan (D) Observe the patient for 24 hours
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of migraines and presents with a 1-day history of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has tried over-the-counter pain medications without relief. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. She appears uncomfortable and is unable to lie flat due to the pain. There is no evidence of a focal neurological deficit. The patient has a migraine attack. The most appropriate next step in management is to treat the migraine attack. The answer is (C) Administer IV sumatriptan.

Q: A 24-year-old woman delivers a baby at term. The Apgar counts are 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Thirty minutes after delivery, the mother’s blood pressure drops to 80/60 mm Hg and her pulse is 124/min. On physical examination, her distal extremities are clammy and cold, and the uterus is boggy. Aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated. After administering 4 units of IV fluids and 4 units of whole blood, her vitals stabilize. The next morning, she says she is unable to lactate when she tries to breastfeed her child. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the failure of lactation in this patient?
(A) Pituitary tumor (B) Remains of placenta in uterus (C) Pituitary infarction (D) Pituitary hemorrhage
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 73-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe back pain. He has no history of recent significant trauma or heavy lifting. He has been compliant with his medications and has no history of substance abuse. He has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. His blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows a well-developed, obese man in moderate distress. There is a prominent abdominal aortic bruit. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An electrocardiogram shows a normal sinus rhythm. A chest x-ray shows a prominent aortic arch. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. He has sudden onset severe back pain, which could be due to aortic dissection. A prominent abdominal aortic bruit supports this diagnosis. The patient has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years, which increases his risk of aortic dissection. The patient's blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg, which is very high and could cause further damage to the aorta. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform an abdominal aortic ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis of aortic dissection. The answer is (D).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fatigue and yellow discoloration of his skin. One week ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.4 g/dl and his mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 39% Hb/cell. A Coombs test is negative. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
(A) Acute myelogenous leukemia (B) Cholecystitis (C) Renal papillary necrosis (D) Splenic sequestration crisis

His hemoglobin concentration is 9.4 g/dl and his mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 39% Hb/cell. A Coombs test is negative. A peripheral blood smear is shown. options: (A) Acute myelogenous leukemia (B) Cholecystitis (C) Renal papillary necrosis (D) Splenic sequestration crisis
outputs:
The patient has a history of upper respiratory tract infection and now presents with jaundice and splenomegaly. His hemoglobin is low, 9.4 g/dL (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), and his mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 39% Hb/cell (normal range 27.5-31.5%). Q: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen for the past 2 hours. She has a history of cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows guarding and rigidity in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An abdominal ultrasound shows a gallstone in the common bile duct. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (B) Open cholecystectomy (C) Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage (D) Conservative management
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis. She now presents with severe pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, guarding, and rigidity. An abdominal ultrasound shows a gallstone in the common bile duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the most appropriate next step in management. ERCP is a minimally invasive procedure that can both diagnose and treat bile duct stones. The answer is (A).

Q: A 7-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and a rash on his face and trunk. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a maculopapular rash on his face and trunk. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a maculopapular rash on his face and trunk, fever, and a crusted lesion on his lower lip. The patient has herpes simplex virus. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous acyclovir. Oral medications may not be effective as the virus is already causing symptoms. The answer is (A).

question: Q: A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a general checkup. She has been doing well in school and has no complaints. The patient has a past medical history of asthma which is controlled with albuterol. She is currently sexually active but states that she uses birth control. She has many friends and states that her mood is typically positive. The patient's last pap smear was 1 year ago. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 68, and her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 65. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 147/108 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's BMI is 19 kg/m^2. Physical exam demonstrates a normal S1 and S2, normal breath sounds, and an abdominal exam that is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
options: (A) Colonoscopy (B) Discontinue birth control and place an intrauterine device (C) Pap smear (D) Recommend weight loss
outputs:
The patient is a 27-year-old woman who is doing well in school and has no complaints. She has a history of asthma, which is controlled with albuterol. She is currently sexually active and uses birth control. She has a positive mood and a normal physical exam. Her last pap smear was 1 year ago. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 68, and her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 65. The patient's BMI is 19 kg/m^2. Given the patient's family history of cancer, it would be appropriate to recommend a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. The answer is (A).

Q: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of left-sided chest pain. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He has no prior history of cardiovascular disease. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-dressed man in moderate distress. There is a 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The apex beat is normal. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V4 to V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (B) Administer aspirin (C) Administer clopidogrel (D) Perform cardiac catheterization
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He has no prior history of cardiovascular disease. He presents with sudden onset left-sided chest pain. His blood pressure is elevated at 180/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The apex beat is normal. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V4 to V6. These findings are consistent with a myocardial infarction (heart attack). The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer sublingual nitroglycerin, which is a medication that can help to relieve chest pain and reduce the risk of further heart damage during a myocardial infarction. The answer is (A).

Q: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has no history of head trauma. Her blood pressure is elevated at 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-appearing woman in moderate distress. There is no evidence of meningism or focal neurological deficits. These findings are consistent with a migraine headache. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer sumatriptan, which is a medication that is often used to treat migraine headaches. The answer is (B).
