Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 25-year-old woman presents generalized abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour. She has also had watery diarrhea for several days with no blood or pus in the stools. She is taking an over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication, which she cannot remember the name of, and drinking oral rehydration solution, which has helped a little. Her past medical history shows she was hospitalized 10 years ago for an appendectomy and 4 years ago for a fractured ulna following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs are pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 14/min with shallow breathing, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, pupils are constricted. Extremities are pale and cold. The abdomen is soft but mildly, diffusely tender to palpation with a palpable bladder. No rebound or guarding. Fingerstick blood glucose is 124 mg/dL. Laboratory tests are pending. A urinary catheter is placed, and intravenous fluids are started. Abdominal imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
(A) Administer naloxone (B) Scopolamine patch (C) Start dextrose infusion (D) Perform a gastric lavage
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 63-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening substernal pain. He has also had fever, chills, and nausea. He has no shortness of breath. He appears uncomfortable. His blood pressure is 190/100 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen. There is a 3/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. There is no radiation of pain. There is no rebound tenderness. There is no guarding. There is no rigidity. Urinalysis shows 3+ protein, 2+ blood, and 1+ white blood cells. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently taking lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Myocardial infarction (B) Pulmonary embolism (C) Pneumonia (D) Acute kidney injury
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He presents with substernal pain, fever, chills, and nausea. His blood pressure is 190/100 mm Hg. There is no guarding. There is no rigidity. Urinalysis shows 3+ protein, 2+ blood, and 1+ white blood cells. The patient has symptoms consistent with possible myocardial infarction. The patient's history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia increases the likelihood of myocardial infarction. The patient's urinalysis shows proteinuria, hematuria, and pyuria, which are consistent with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The patient's symptoms and urinalysis are consistent with possible myocardial infarction and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The most likely diagnosis is myocardial infarction. The answer is (A).

Q: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the ED following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs on presentation are T 99.0 F, BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air. Exam demonstrates abdominal wall rigidity, involuntary guarding, and tenderness on light percussion. Bedside sonography shows evidence for hemoperitoneum. Despite administering more intravenous fluids, repeat vitals are T 98.9 F, BP 82/50 mm hg, HR 180 bpm, RR 20/min, SpO2 97% on room air. Which of the following is the best next step?

question: Q: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the ED following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs on presentation are T 99.0 F, BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air. outputs:
The patient has a history of a motor vehicle accident and is complaining of extreme abdominal pain, which worsened over the past 30 minutes. He has signs of abdominal wall rigidity, involuntary guarding, and tenderness on light percussion. Bedside sonography shows evidence for hemoperitoneum. The patient's vital signs show a tachycardia and hypotension. This suggests that the patient is bleeding. The patient needs immediate fluid resuscitation and blood transfusions. The patient's condition is unstable, and immediate surgical intervention is required. The answer is (D).

Q: A 38-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity presents to the emergency department with acute onset left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient has signs and symptoms of acute coronary syndrome. The patient needs immediate medical therapy. The answer is (D).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 74-year-old man undergoes an open cholecystectomy. Surgery is performed under general anesthesia for which the patient is intubated with an endotracheal tube. Directly following the procedure, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is extubated as soon as he showed signs of alertness. Five minutes later, he becomes unresponsive. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He underwent stenting of the right coronary artery 10 years ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 weeks ago for surgery. He drinks one to two beers daily. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 73%. He is put on a non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%. Three minutes later, he is still unresponsive. His arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.32
PCO2 33 mm Hg
PO2 73 mm Hg
HCO3 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 73%
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
(A) Perform tracheostomy (B) Continue using the non-rebreather mask (C) Reintubate (D) Start BiPAP
A: Let's think step by step.

outputs:

Q: A 66-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive in his home. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with heart failure. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking, which are risk factors for heart failure. The patient's electrocardiogram shows a complete left bundle branch block, which is a specific type of conduction disturbance in the heart, indicating that the electrical activity of the heart is abnormal. Q: An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a 33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2) from an uncomplicated pregnancy at 39 weeks. He has met all developmental milestones and is up to date on all vaccinations. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 137/min, respiratory rate 25/min, and temperature 36.7°C (97.0°F). His length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile. On physical examination, blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae are noted. Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits for his age. There is joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the tough. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician palpates his leg. The patient’s X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
(A) Insufficient production of procollagen type 1 (B) Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1 (C) Defective collagen type 3 (D) Dysfunctional structure of laminins
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a 33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2) from an uncomplicated pregnancy at 39 weeks. He has met all developmental milestones and is up to date on all vaccinations. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. His length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile. On physical examination, blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae are noted. options: (A) Insufficient production of procollagen type 1 (B) Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1 (C) Defective collagen type 3 (D) Dysfunctional structure of laminins
outputs:
The patient is an 11-month-old male infant who is unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on his right leg. He has a history of hitting his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the touch. The patient’s X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. The patient's symptoms are consistent with a fracture. The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. The answer is (D).

Q: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough productive of rust-colored sputum. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 20-pack-year smoking history. She has no known allergies. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows the patient to be in moderate respiratory distress. There is a cardiac murmur, and lung fields show diffuse wheezing and bilateral crackles. The patient appears diaphoretic. There are no signs of jugular venous distension. The patient has a history of smoking and has symptoms consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer oxygen and give an albuterol nebulizer treatment (B) Order a chest x-ray (C) Perform an electrocardiogram (D) Administer intravenous furosemide
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and symptoms consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is in moderate respiratory distress, and lung fields show diffuse wheezing and bilateral crackles. The patient appears diaphoretic. These are all signs of an exacerbation of COPD. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer oxygen and give an albuterol nebulizer treatment. This will help to open up the patient's airways and relieve her respiratory distress. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of previous knee injuries. She has been doing aerobics 3 times a week for the past 6 months. She has no known allergies. Her temperature is 36.7°C (97.9°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the medial tibial plateau. There is no erythema or swelling. The patient can walk without assistance. The patient has no history of knee injuries and has been doing aerobics regularly. This, combined with the physical examination findings, suggests a possible stress fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an anteroposterior and lateral knee radiograph (B) Order a knee MRI (C) Immobilize the knee in a hinged brace (D) Administer intravenous morphine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of previous knee injuries. She has been doing aerobics 3 times a week for the past 6 months. She has no known allergies. The patient can walk without assistance, and there is no erythema or swelling. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a possible stress fracture. The most appropriate next step in management would be to order an anteroposterior and lateral knee radiograph. This will help to confirm the diagnosis of a stress fracture. The answer is (A).

The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room with swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg that started 2 hours ago. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father has a history of pulmonary embolism. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since he started college 3 years ago. He appears very distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 30.7 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm3, a prothrombin time of 11 seconds, an activated partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the activated partial thromboplastin time is 30 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
(A) Antithrombin III deficiency (B) Factor V Leiden (C) Protein C deficiency (D) Antiphospholipid syndrome
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room with swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg that started 2 hours ago. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father has a history of pulmonary embolism. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since he started college 3 years ago. He appears very distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 30.7 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm3, a prothrombin time of 11 seconds, an activated partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the activated partial thromboplastin time is 30 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
options: (A) Antithrombin III deficiency (B) Factor V Leiden (C) Protein C deficiency (D) Antiphospholipid syndrome
outputs:
The patient has a swollen and painful left lower leg. He has a history of smoking and a family history of pulmonary embolism. His platelet count is normal, but he has positive fibrin split products. The ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the activated partial thromboplastin time is 30 seconds. The patient's symptoms are consistent with deep venous thrombosis. The patient has a positive family history of pulmonary embolism, and the patient's age and smoking history are risk factors for deep venous thrombosis. The patient's positive fibrin split products suggest that the patient has a thrombotic disorder. The patient's activated partial thromboplastin time is 30 seconds, which suggests that the patient has a thrombotic disorder. The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is Factor V Leiden, a thrombotic disorder that increases the risk of deep venous thrombosis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of acute onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He is unable to ambulate without assistance. He is currently taking metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and his blood glucose level is 300 mg/dL. Physical examination shows a dense left hemiparesis and dysarthria. There is no evidence of aphasia or neglect. The patient's National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score is 17. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) (B) Perform computed tomography (CT) angiography of the neck and brain (C) Administer intravenous glucose and insulin (D) Perform an electroencephalogram (EEG)
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. He presents with acute onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. His blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and his blood glucose level is 300 mg/dL. Physical examination shows a dense left hemiparesis and dysarthria. There is no evidence of aphasia or neglect. The patient's National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score is 17. The patient is having an acute ischemic stroke. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). tPA is a thrombolytic agent that is effective in treating acute ischemic stroke. It works by breaking down blood clots and restoring blood flow to the affected area. The answer is (A).

Q: In a small town with a population of 10,000 people, the prevalence of alcohol use is estimated to be 30%. A study is done with a null hypothesis that there is no association between alcohol use and gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The data obtained shows, of the 200 alcoholics who were followed-up, 30 developed GERD; and out of the 400 non-alcoholics, 30 developed GERD. What fraction of GERD can be prevented in the general population if alcohol is no longer consumed in this town?
(A) 45/195 (B) 30/400 (C) (30/200) / (30/400) (D) 30/200
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: In a small town with a population of 10,000 people, the prevalence of alcohol use is estimated to be 30%. A study is done with a null hypothesis that there is no association between alcohol use and gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The data obtained shows, of the 200 alcoholics who were followed-up, 30 developed GERD; and out of the 400 non-alcoholics, 30 developed GERD. What fraction of GERD can be prevented in the general population if alcohol is no longer consumed in this town?
outputs:
The prevalence of alcohol use in the population is 30%. The number of alcoholics who developed GERD is 30. The number of non-alcoholics who developed GERD is 30. The relative risk of GERD in alcoholics compared to non-alcoholics is (30/200) / (30/400) = 1.5. To calculate the fraction of GERD that can be prevented in the general population if alcohol is no longer consumed, we need to calculate the attributable risk. The attributable risk is the difference in the incidence of GERD between alcoholics and non-alcoholics, divided by the incidence of GERD in the population. The attributable risk is (30/200) - (30/400) = 0.15. To convert this to a fraction, we divide by 100: 0.15/100 = 0.15%. Therefore, approximately 0.15% of GERD cases in the general population can be prevented if alcohol is no longer consumed. The answer is (D).

Q: A 55-year-old woman with a history of smoking and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of knee trauma or injury. She has been using over-the-counter acetaminophen and ibuprofen without relief. She denies any recent changes in her exercise routine or environment. She is currently taking albuterol, ipratropium, and fluticasone. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a swollen and tender left knee with a limited range of motion. There is no erythema or warmth. The patient walks with a cane and appears uncomfortable. Radiographs of the knee show no evidence of osteoarthritis or fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous (IV) ketorolac (B) Order magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the knee (C) Begin physical therapy (D) Prescribe celecoxib
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and COPD. She presents with a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain without any history of trauma or injury. She has been using over-the-counter acetaminophen and ibuprofen without relief. She is currently taking albuterol, ipratropium, and fluticasone. Her physical examination shows a swollen and tender left knee with a limited range of motion, and radiographs of the knee show no evidence of osteoarthritis or fracture. Given the patient's history of smoking and COPD, it is likely that her knee pain is related to her respiratory disease. The most appropriate next step in management would be to order a chest x-ray to assess for any changes in her lung function. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of sudden severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He takes lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. He appears uncomfortable and has a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse of 80/min, respirations of 18/min, and blood pressure of 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a non-focal neurological examination. The patient is alert and able to speak in full sentences. A non-contrast head CT scan shows a 5-mm left parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous (IV) metoprolol (B) Administer IV furosemide (C) Administer IV phenytoin

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 41-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaints of abdominal discomfort and cramping for the past 4 months. He also mentions that he has grossly bloody stool and most of the time an urge to defecate. He has a history of bulimia with laxative abuse several years ago. He admits having lost about 5 lb in the past month. His temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 105/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, a mild conjunctival pallor is evident, and the rectum is erythematous, indurated, and tender. Colonoscopy demonstrates continuous mucosal lesions throughout the rectum to the hepatic flexure of the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Ulcerative colitis (B) Celiac disease (C) Irritable bowel syndrome (D) Crohn’s disease
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 41-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaints of abdominal discomfort and cramping for the past 4 months. options: (A) Ulcerative colitis (B) Celiac disease (C) Irritable bowel syndrome (D) Crohn’s disease
outputs:
The patient has abdominal discomfort, cramping, and grossly bloody stool. He also has a history of bulimia with laxative abuse several years ago and has lost about 5 lb in the past month. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with inflammatory bowel disease. The patient's history of bulimia with laxative abuse suggests that he may have developed a malabsorption syndrome, which can lead to inflammation in the colon. The patient's age and symptoms also suggest that the most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her friends because of sudden onset of severe headache, vomiting, and altered mental status. She was well 2 hours ago. On arrival, her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a woman in moderate distress, with aphasia, right-sided hemiparesis, and gaze preference to the left. There is no neck stiffness or Kernig sign. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A noncontrast head CT shows a large, irregular, heterogeneous mass in the right hemisphere, which is centered within the sylvian fissure and projects to the inferior frontal gyrus. The mass shows a peripheral rim of calcification. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 10,000/mm3, platelet count of 150,000/mm3, and hemoglobin of 13.5 g/dL. The patient is immediately taken to the operating room for an emergency craniotomy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Glioblastoma multiforme (B) Metastatic adenocarcinoma (C) Cerebral abscess (D) Arteriovenous malformation
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden onset of severe headache, vomiting, and altered mental status. She has aphasia, right-sided hemiparesis, and gaze preference to the left. The noncontrast head CT shows a large, irregular, heterogeneous mass in the right hemisphere, which is centered within the sylvian fissure and projects to the inferior frontal gyrus. The mass shows a peripheral rim of calcification. The patient is immediately taken to the operating room for an emergency craniotomy. The most likely diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of a 2-year history of progressive weakness in her hands and feet. She also notices that her voice has become hoarse and that she has lost 20 pounds over the past year. She has no history of neurological or psychiatric disorders. On physical examination, there is mild atrophy of the hand and feet muscles, and the patient has difficulty walking heel-to-toe. There is no evidence of sensory loss or muscle wasting. The patient's voice is hoarse, and there is no evidence of nasal twang or nasal polyps. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. The patient's CBC, electrolytes, and liver function tests are normal. A thyroid profile shows a T4 of 80 ng/dL and a T3 of 80 ng/dL. The patient's serum creatinine kinase level is 200 IU/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (B) Hypothyroidism (C) Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (D) Guillain-Barré syndrome
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has progressive weakness in her hands and feet, hoarse voice, and weight loss over the past year. She has no history of neurological or psychiatric disorders. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a neurodegenerative disorder. The patient's T4 and T3 levels are normal, ruling out

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). (A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 45-year-old man presents to your office with a 2-year history of moderate-to-severe pelvic pain, irritative voiding urinary symptoms (frequency and dysuria), and occasional frank blood in his semen with painful ejaculation. He has been evaluated by several practitioners, who have all prescribed antimicrobial therapy, including ciprofloxacin, with no improvement and leading to emotional distress and sleep disturbances. The physical examination is unremarkable, except for a mildly tender prostate, without masses or nodules. There are no testicular masses, hernias, or hemorrhoids. Additionally to this health issue, you have also been following him for recurrent abdominal pain, periods of constipation and diarrhea, and fatigability, with all test results within the normal range thus far. A summary of recent tests is shown in the following table:
Urine test
Sample White cells Culture
Mid-stream urine Negative Negative
Expressed prostatic secretion Positive Negative
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
(A) Benign prostatic hyperplasia (B) Chronic, non-bacterial prostatitis (C) Chronic prostatitis by resistant Escherichia coli (D) Interstitial cystitis
A: Let's think step by step.

outputs:

Q: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe left-sided chest pain for the past 30 minutes. She is diaphoretic and has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 104/min. Physical examination shows a regular heart rhythm, but there is a grade II/VI systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. There is no evidence of a pulmonary embolism. An ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads V3 through V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer aspirin (B) Administer clopidogrel (C) Administer heparin (D) Perform a cardiac catheterization
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe left-sided chest pain for the past 30 minutes. She is diaphoretic and has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 104/min. Physical examination shows a regular heart rhythm, but there is a grade II/VI systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. There is no evidence of a pulmonary embolism. An ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads V3 through V6. This is diagnostic of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (STEMI). The most appropriate next step in management is to immediately administer aspirin and clopidogrel, as well as heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin. The cardiac catheterization is not an emergency procedure and can be done later. The answer is (A).

Q: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 110/min. Physical examination shows a regular heart rhythm, but there is a grade III/VI systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. There is no evidence of a pulmonary embolism. An ECG shows ST segment depression in leads V3 through V6. Chest x-ray shows a prominent aortic arch, prominent pulmonary arteries, and a flattened diaphragm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer aspirin (B) Administer clopidogrel (C) Administer heparin (D) Perform a cardiac catheterization
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-day history of worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 110/min. Physical examination shows a regular heart rhythm, but there is a grade III/VI systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. There is no evidence of a pulmonary embolism

question: Q: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. The patient undergoes an exploratory laparotomy, during which, it is discovered that his splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk. The surgeon ligates the splenic artery at its origin. Which of the following arteries will now be hypoperfused as a result?
options: (A) Left gastric artery (B) Gastroduodenal artery (C) Left gastroepiploic artery (D) Common hepatic artery
outputs:
The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk and supplies the spleen. The splenic artery is ligated at its origin. Therefore, the spleen will now be hypoperfused. The spleen receives blood from the splenic artery, which is a branch of the celiac trunk. The celiac trunk also gives rise to the left gastric artery, gastroduodenal artery, and left gastroepiploic artery. These arteries will not be hypoperfused because they are not affected by the ligation of the splenic artery. The common hepatic artery supplies the liver and is not affected by the ligation of the splenic artery. The answer is (D).

Q: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset left-sided chest pain. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is currently taking lisinopril and simvastatin. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a soft, non-tender abdomen with no rebound tenderness or guarding. The patient has a decreased breath sound on the left side of her chest. A chest x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) CT angiography of the chest (B) Ultrasound of the abdomen (C) MRI of the chest (D) Thoracentesis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden onset left-sided chest pain, which could be due to a pulmonary embolism. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which increases the likelihood of cardiovascular disease. Physical examination shows a soft, non-tender abdomen with no rebound tenderness or guarding, which suggests that the pain is not due to an abdominal cause. A chest x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion, which could be due to a pulmonary embolism. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism. CT angiography of the chest is the best test to diagnose pulmonary embolism. The answer is (A).

Q: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive in her home. She has a history of dementia and has been taking donepezil. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a quiet, unresponsive patient with no focal neurological deficits. There is no evidence of trauma or injury. The patient's donepezil level is within the therapeutic range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer naloxone (B) Administer flumazenil (C) Perform an electroencephalogram (EEG) (D) Admit the patient for observation
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of dementia and is taking donepezil, which is a medication used to treat dementia. The patient is unresponsive and has no focal neurological deficits. The donepezil level is within the therapeutic range, which suggests that the medication is not causing the patient's symptoms. The patient's symptoms could be due to a medication side effect, but it is unlikely given the patient's history of dementia. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform an electroencephalogram (EEG) to rule out a seizure disorder. The answer is (C).

Q: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening left knee pain. He plays basketball 3 times a week and has been using a brace to support his knee. He has no history of previous knee injuries or surgery. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling over the left knee, which is warm to the touch. There is no erythema or effusion. The patient has moderate pain with flexion

The following are multiple choice questions (with answers) about professional medicine.

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy born by cesarean delivery is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B. The mother made it to all of her prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of folic acid since conception. She gave up smoking when she discovered she was pregnant. The infant’s heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 48/min, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg. APGAR testing exhibits a score of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The head is normocephalic. No neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine. There is strong flexion in all 4 extremities. Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact. Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities. Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child?
Hepatitis B serology
HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
IgM HBc negative
Total anti-HBc positive
Anti-HBs negative
Anti-HBc negative
HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL
Alanine transferase normal
(A) Administer hepatitis B vaccine (B) Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) (C) Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG (D) Check hepatitis B serology
A: Let's think step by step.
